title: Angus Black
text:
Angus William "Gus" Black (6 May 1925 – 14 February 2018) was a Scottish international <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> player, who played for and the <a href="British%20and%20Irish%20Lions">Lions</a>.
Rugby Union career.
Amateur career.
Black played for <a href="Edinburgh%20University%20RFC">Edinburgh University</a>.
He went on to play for <a href="Leicester%20Tigers">Leicester</a> and <a href="Bristol%20Bears">Bristol</a> during his <a href="Conscription%20in%20the%20United%20Kingdom%23After%201945">National Service</a>.
He played for the <a href="Royal%20Air%20Force%20Rugby%20Union">Royal Air Force Rugby Union</a> in 1954.
Provincial career.
Black was capped for <a href="Edinburgh%20District%20%28rugby%20union%29">Edinburgh District</a>.
He played for the <a href="Cities%20District%20%28rugby%20union%29">Cities District</a> side in their match against <a href="Australia%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Australia</a> in October 1947.
He turned out for the <a href="Scotland%20Possibles">Scotland Possibles</a> side in 1947.
International career.
Black made his first international appearance on New Year's Day 1947 while studying <a href="medical%20education">medicine</a> at the <a href="University%20of%20Edinburgh">University of Edinburgh</a>. He also played for <a href="Edinburgh%20University%20RFC">Edinburgh University rugby team</a>, and was on the <a href="1950%20British%20Lions%20tour%20to%20New%20Zealand%20and%20Australia">1950 British Lions tour to New Zealand and Australia</a> where he played in two tests, playing in a 9–9 draw in <a href="Dunedin">Dunedin</a> and a 0–8 loss in <a href="Christchurch">Christchurch</a>.
Death.
Black lived in <a href="Lundin%20Links">Lundin Links</a> in <a href="Fife">Fife</a>. After moving into a care home in the 1990s, Black died in February 2018 and at the time of his death was the oldest living Lions player.
